section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Gg and Hh, engage children with a chant, and introduce a new vocabulary word (carry).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How does Luis help the children?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences; make predictions.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Persist in tasks.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Gh and Hh.
Read A Good Game and Hearts .
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Look at the pictures in that book. How is it different from Biblioburro?
Pretend you are waiting for the biblioburro. What book do you hope Luis will bring?
How many letter b’s are in biblioburro? Say it slowly and listen for the /b/ sound.
Let’s work together to write a thank you note to Luis. We will pretend we are from El Tormento.
Let’s make a biblioburro out of tin foil and colorful tissue!
Use your fingers to trace the letter h in this shaving cream.
Build a scene to show what El Tormento looked like.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders:Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder persist in tasks, and introduce related vocabulary words.
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Biblioburro.
Read closely to find examples of persistence and talk about persisting in a task.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences.
Persist in tasks.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Consistently use the counting sequence in order during different counting activities.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

small-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Number tiles from one to ten

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children identify the problem (the numbers are out of order).
Have children work in teams to complete the challenging task of putting numbers in order from one to ten.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me a page that shows persistence in this book.
Pretend you are Luis and are passing out books. Some friends can act like the children.
How many letters in “Biblioburro”? Look at the book cover and then count them. You can use Connecting Cubes to help you.
Can you change this story so it has a different ending? Write it or show me in pictures.
Make a picture to show your favorite part of Biblioburro.
Let’s use foam letters and stamp pads to write words. What words can you make?
Can you build something using only one color of plastic bricks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Biblioburro: A True Story From Colombia by Jeanette Winter. Copyright © 2010 by Jeanette Winter. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement withBeach Lane Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon& Schuster, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill make inferences and introduce the vocabulary (borrow).
Start Story Time by revisiting Biblioburro and asking the Guiding Question, What can we learn from the pictures in this book?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences; make predictions.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Persist in tasks.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children use play clay to recreate landforms, animals, and plants of the jungle(rain forest).
Assist children as they label their creations.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the environment in that book different from and like yours?
Imagine you have to travel with a lot of books from your neighborhood to a place far away. How would you get there?
Find a leaf from a tree in your neighborhood and make a leaf rubbing. How is it different from the leaves you see in Biblioburro?
Make up symbols and label objects in your classroom. Why did you choose those symbols?
How can you make a pocket for carrying a book?
Use Magnetic Letters to spell out library and words from the book.
How can you build a little house like the ones in Biblioburro?Let’s see!

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Biblioburro: A True Story From Colombia by Jeanette Winter. Copyright © 2010 by Jeanette Winter. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Beach Lane Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas:Super Jobs

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about neighborhood helpers and introduce vocabulary words (doctor, firefighter).
Start Story Time by connecting the texts Super Jobs and Biblioburro.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question, Who are the people who help in our community?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences; make predictions.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Persist in tasks.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Encourage children to act like different helpers in the community.
Guide discussion by asking prompting questions about different helpers in the community.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Who do you think is the most helpful in this story?
Dress up like your favorite neighborhood helper.
Can you think of any plant, insect, or animal helpers? How do they help?
Together, let’s write a thank-you note to your favorite helper.
Use the materials to make a present to include with your thank-you note.
I will write your name. You trace it with a pencil.
Let’s build places in our town where helpers work. Where should we place the buildings? Should they be tall buildings or small buildings? Are there trees around?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Biblioburro: A True Story From Colombia by Jeanette Winter. Copyright © 2010 by Jeanette Winter. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Beach Lane Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster Children’s Publishing Division, a division of Simon & Schuster, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to bring books to children, talk about books, and introduce vocabulary (stream).
Start Story Time by revisiting Biblioburro and asking, How can we help in our community?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences; make predictions.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Persist in tasks.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment, such as hills, rivers, roads, lakes, and familiar buildings.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: How can we be helpers in school?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Imagine this story was about helpers in your neighborhood. Who might be in it?
Pretend you are a firefighter. What kind of clothes do you need to wear?
Let’s create a list of all the helpers we can think of. I’ll write them, and then we’ll count them!
Imagine I am a chef and you are interviewing me. I’ll help you write one question each. Then, you can ask your question and I’ll answer!
Let’s make thank-you cards to school helpers. Who should we thank first?
Let’s use Magnetic Letters to make words from Biblioburro.
Can you help build a box for people to use to leave each other nice notes?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Make inferences and predictions about text.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Demonstrate that the order of the counting sequence is always the same, regardless of what is counted.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally shares meaning.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representation.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Try a new approach or new tasks.
Identify and create common features in the natural environment.
